fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}. An algebra for \mathbb {T} is defined to be a T-algebra X satisfying the following unit and associativity laws:
Let F be an endofunctor on a category \mathcal {C}; an algebra for F is defined to be an object X\in \mathcal {C} equipped with a mapping {FX}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _{X}}}{X}.

Let F be an endofunctor on a category \mathcal {C} and let X,Y be a pair of algebras for F; a homomorphism of algebras from X to Y is given by a morphism {X}\xrightarrow {{h}}{Y} in \mathcal {C} that preserves the algebra structure in the following sense:

Let X be a an algebra for an endofunctor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{F}}{\mathcal {C}}, and let {X}\xrightarrow {{x}}{X} be an endomorphism in \mathcal {C}. We define the restriction of X by {X}\xrightarrow {{x}}{X} to be the algebra x\cdot X whose carrier is X with {FX}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _{x\cdot X}}}{X} defined to be the following composite:

Let \mathbb {T} \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}. An algebra for \mathbb {T} is defined to be a T-algebra X satisfying the following unit and associativity laws:
We shall refer to an algebra for the underlying endofunctor of a monad as a weak algebra, following Joyal and Moerdijk.

fr:title.text: The induced monad algebra on a fixed point

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The induced monad algebra on a fixed point

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We must show that our construction in fact gives rise to a monad algebra.

fr:title.text: Unitality of the induced monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unitality of the induced monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T} for which the algebra map is invertible by {X}\xrightarrow {{\pi _{X}}}{TX}. Then the induced monad algebra \bar {X} is unital.
We are trying to check that the following morphism is an identity:

fr:title.text: Associativity of the induced monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associativity of the induced monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T} for which the algebra map is invertible by {X}\xrightarrow {{\pi _{X}}}{TX}. Then the induced monad algebra \bar {X} is associative.
We are trying to check that the following identity holds:

fr:title.text: The induced monad algebra is a monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The induced monad algebra is a monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T} for which the algebra map is invertible. Then the induced monad algebra \bar {X} is in fact a monad algebra.
Because it is unital and associative.

fr:title.text: Lifting homomorphisms to the induced monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lifting homomorphisms to the induced monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C} and let I be an invertible weak algebra for \mathbb {T}; let X be an arbitrary \mathbb {T}-algebra equipped with an endomap {X}\xrightarrow {{x}}{X}\in \mathcal {C}. Then a homomorphism {I}\xrightarrow {{j}}{x\cdot X} also tracks a homomorphism {\bar {I}}\xrightarrow {{j}}{X}, where \bar {I} is the induced monad algebra of I and x\cdot X is the restriction of X along x.
Suppose that {I}\xrightarrow {{j}}{x\cdot X} is a homomorphism; we must check that the same map tracks a homomorphism {\bar {I}}\xrightarrow {{j}}{X}.

fr:title.text: Lifting homomorphisms to the induced successor algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lifting homomorphisms to the induced successor algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} \equiv {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C} and let I be an invertible weak algebra for \mathbb {T}; let X be an arbitrary successor algebra. Then a homomorphism {I}\xrightarrow {{j}}{s\cdot X} also tracks a successor algebra homomorphism {\bar {I}}\xrightarrow {{j}}{X}, where \bar {I} is the induced successor algebra of I and s\cdot X is the successor restriction of X.
We have already seen that {I}\xrightarrow {{j}}{s\cdot X} tracks an algebra homomorphism {\bar {I}}\xrightarrow {{j}}{X}. It remains to show that this homomorphism preserves the successor operation.

fr:title.text: The induced successor algebra on a fixed point

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The induced successor algebra on a fixed point

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T}\equiv {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T}. The monad algebra \bar {X} induced by X can be equipped with the structure of a successor algebra by defining {X}\xrightarrow {{s_{\bar {X}}}}{X} to be the following map:

fr:title.text: Associativity of the induced monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associativity of the induced monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T} for which the algebra map is invertible by {X}\xrightarrow {{\pi _{X}}}{TX}. Then the induced monad algebra \bar {X} is associative.
We are trying to check that the following identity holds:

Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}. A successor algebra for \mathbb {T} is defined to be a algebra X for \mathbb {T} together with a morphism {X}\xrightarrow {{s_{X}}}{X} in \mathcal {C} called the successor map.

fr:title.text: The induced monad algebra is a monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The induced monad algebra is a monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T} for which the algebra map is invertible. Then the induced monad algebra \bar {X} is in fact a monad algebra.
Because it is unital and associative.

fr:title.text: Unitality of the induced monad algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unitality of the induced monad algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {T} be a monad on a category \mathcal {C}, and let X be a weak algebra for \mathbb {T} for which the algebra map is invertible by {X}\xrightarrow {{\pi _{X}}}{TX}. Then the induced monad algebra \bar {X} is unital.
We are trying to check that the following morphism is an identity:
Let F be an endofunctor on a category \mathcal {C}; an algebra for F is defined to be an object X\in \mathcal {C} equipped with a mapping {FX}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _{X}}}{X}.
